Subject: How should protected inherited method be tested?

I read the article via the FAQ's about how to test protected/private
method=
s with JUnit, and it works fine for non-inherited methods.

But how should =
i test protected inherited methods? The methods should
initially be tested =
in the parent class, but sometimes the inherited
methods are needed to veri=
fy tests on the inherited class, e.g. a
get-method.

For example:
class A{
=
  protected int no =3D 1;

  protected changeNo(){
    no =3D 2;
  }

  pro=
tected getNo{
    return no;
  }
}

class B entends A{
  protected changeNo=
(){
    no =3D 3;
  }
}

When testing changeNo in class B, I would like to =
verify that no =3D=3D 3,
 but I cannot access no or A.getNo since they are =
not returned in
object.getClass().getDeclaredFields() or
object.getClass().=
getDeclaredMethods() when called on class B.

I could put all my tests in t=
he same package as the classes being
tested, but I would like to avoid that=
.

- Louise
